awd_titl_txt: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: Enabling GPUs as First-Class Computing Engines
awd_abstract_narration:
Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) are rapidly bringing the computing
power traditionally associated with massively parallel supercomputers
into the mainstream devices we use today. They have the power to
revolutionize computing by enabling orders of magnitude faster and
more efficient execution of many applications. Unfortunately, many
modern applications and users cannot take advantage of the computing
capability present in today's GPUs because today's GPUs are used as
secondary devices to the much less powerful CPUs. As a result, the massive
computing power of GPUs gets wasted and underutilized for a large
number of important applications.

This project aims to take a fresh and comprehensive look at GPU design
with the goal of enabling GPUs as first-class computing engines that
can benefit an overwhelming majority of real-world applications and
users. To this end, this project systematically investigates the
hardware/software design space of three new execution models, which
progressively turn a GPU into an independent, first-class compute
engine in a hybrid computing system: 1) an enhanced master-slave model
where the GPU is able to perform multiple-application execution, 2) a
new peer-to-peer model where the GPU is autonomous of the CPU, 3) a
hybrid model where GPUs and CPUs are integrated on the same die and
are equals from the applications' and system's viewpoint. The project
comprehensively develops software, hardware and software/hardware
cooperative scheduling, resource management, and system design
techniques for all three models.

If successful, this project can pave the way to making GPUs
first-class computing engines used in all aspects of our everyday
lives for a majority of applications. Doing so is not only expected to
lead to much higher degrees of energy efficiency and user productivity
but can also potentially enable new applications and devices that can
take advantage GPUs.

por.por_cntn:
Graphics Processing Units are rapidly bringing the processing power traditionally associated with massively parallel computers into the mainstream devices we use today. They have the power to revolutionize computing by enabling orders of magnitude faster and more efficient execution of many applications. However, many applications still cannot take full advantage of GPUs because a GPU is used as a slave device to the master CPUs and lacks the capability to independently orchestrate all aspects of program execution. This leads to the large underutilization of GPU resources for many general-purpose codes (as past works, including ours, showed), causing energy/performance waste, which prevents many programmers from using GPUs’ massive computing power. Yet, the best execution model and software/hardware design choices for a GPU system are unclear. Many design problems abound spanning software and hardware, which need to be answered methodically to make the most effective use of GPUs.

This project aimed to take a fresh and comprehensive look at GPU design with the goal of enabling GPUs as first-class computing devices that can benefit an overwhelming majority of real-world applications. The vision of the project was to develop software, hardware and hardware/software cooperative techniques to maximize GPUs’ effectiveness.

The project resulted in many new discoveries and techniques, including:

  • more efficiency in GPU utilization, through the development that allow increased utilization and better adaptibility of programs to the hardware resources available in each GPU model
  • reduced energy consumption, by developing mechanisms to perform efficient data compression in hardware
  • higher performance and fairness in heterogeneous systems, by developing memory scheduling techniques that can differentiate between CPU, GPU, and hardware accelerator requests to memory
  • better GPU memory utilization, through the use of techniques that are aware of the behavior of each warp
  • a new technique to offload some of the GPU computation to in-memory processing units
  • new techniques to improve virtual memory support in GPUs, by enabling application-transparent support for huge pages and alleviating pressure on the limited hardware resources
  • a new technique that can predict values being returned by load instructions without incurring high overhead, which improves GPU performance at low cost
  • a new method for genome sequencing, which takes advantage of the high throughput available in GPUs through smart memory utilization

In the end, this project educated and trained at least 10 graduate, 4 undergraduate, and 2 high school student, and produced 6 Ph.D. dissertations. It also trained 2 postdocs and at least 2 visiting students from other universities.  Our findings produced more than 25 papers at top venues.  The project also resulted in new open course lectures and materials that were released online via Youtube, free of charge to anyone.  As part of the project, there were many open source code releases, which are available for anyone to use at http://www.ece.cmu.edu/~safari/tools.html and https://github.com/CMU-SAFARI. We also delivered more than 50 lectures worldwide, including at least 10 keynote speeches and 2 distinguished lectures, in both industry and academia, to disseminate the results of the project and educate students and researchers.

This was a collaborative project with Penn State.
